questions.question:
Question 1: Which of the following is a characteristic difference between a typical cervical and thoracic 
vertebra?

options.a: Cervical vertebrae have longer spinous processes
options.c: Thoracic vertebrae foramina are bigger than the body
options.d: Thoracic vertebrae have turbercles on transverse processes

questions.explanation:
The typical cervical vertebrae are characterized by a foramen in the transverse process called the 
foramen transversarium. This foramen transversarium transmits the vertebral artery and vein, along with a branch from 
the cervicothoracic ganglion (vertebral nerve). Lateral parts of the transverse processes of the 
cervical vertebrae also contain the anterior and posterior tubercles. The images given below illustrate a typical cervical and thoracic vertebrae respectively. Feature 
Typical cervical vertebrae 
Typical thoracic vertebrae Vertebral body 
Smaller and thinner 
Intermediate in size between 
cervical and lumbarCostal fac

es in a distinct tubercle Spinous processes 
Horizontally behind the body and usually bifid (C1-C5) 1132 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 2: What is the number of bones in the vertebral column?
questions.explanation:
The vertebral column consists of 33 bones. Generally, the number of vertebrae found in each 
segment are as follows: • 7 cervical • 12 thoracic • 5 lumbar • 5 sacral • 4 coccygeal However, this total is subject to frequent variability, and there have been reports of variation 
between 32 and 35 vertebrae. The total length of vertebral column is about 70 cm in males and about 60 cm in females on an 
average. Fibrocartilaginous intervertebral discs separate neighboring vertebrae in the cervical, 
thoracic and lumbar region (except the first 2 cervical vertebrae). The vertebral column supports 
the trunk, protects the spinal cord and nerves, and provide attachments for muscles. It is also an 
important site of hematopoiesis throughout life. The image given below illustrates the adult vertebral column. 1133 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following pairs of 'vertebral segment-normal curvature' is incorrectly matched?
questions.explanation:
The cervical-kyphosis pair is incorrectly matched. The cervical part of the vertebral column 
normally demonstrates lordosis. During embryonic life, the body appears flexed and has 2 primary spinal curvatures. These are the 
thoracic and the pelvic curves, which are convex dorsally. After birth, functional muscle 
development leads to the early appearance of secondary spinal curvatures. These are the cervical 
and the lumbar curves, both of which are convex forwards (lordosis). Normal adult curvatures of the vertebral column are as follows: • The cervical curve is lordosis (convex forwards) • The thoracic curve is kyphosis (convex dorsally) • The lumbar curve is lordosis (convex forwards) • The pelvic curve is concave anteroinferiorly The image given below illustrates the adult vertebral column. 1134 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 4: Which statement regarding normal vertebral column curvature is false?

options.b: Thoracic curve develops when the infant starts walking.
options.c: Cervical curve appears when the infant starts supporting its head.
options.d: Lumbar curve appears when the child assumes the upright posture.

questions.explanation:
The thoracic curvature is a primary curve and is developed during embryonic life itself. Both the primary curves (thoracic and pelvic) that appear during embryonic life are convex 
dorsally. After birth, functional muscle development results in the appearance of secondary 
cervical and lumbar spinal curvatures in the sagittal plane. • The secondary cervical curvature occurs with the development of function in the muscles 
responsible for the head extension. • The secondary lumbar curvature occurs with the development of function in the muscles 
responsible for sitting upright and walking.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 32-year-old man suffered from iatrogenic trauma of the craniovertebral joint following 
occipitocervical fusion and stabilization surgery. Which of the following structures are not 
included in this joint?
questions.explanation:
The craniovertebral joints do not include the wings of the sphenoid. These connect the cranium to the vertebral column. • They include the atlanto-occipital joints and atlanto-axial joints. • The bones involved include the occipital condyles, the atlas, and the axis. These joints are specialized to provide greater mobility than seen in the rest of the axial skeleton. 
Together, they function as a universal joint that allows horizontal and vertical scanning 
movements of the head. Occipitocervical fusion and stabilization surgery is the treatment of choice for patients with 
occipitocervical pathologies including trauma, rheumatoid arthritis, congenital malformations, 
neoplasms, and degeneration. High degree of mobility and the sharp angle at which the occiput 
meets the upper cervical spine, makes rigid surgical fixation challenging. 1135 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: The movements at the  
 joint permit a person to look to the right and left.
questions.explanation:
The movements at the atlanto-axial joint allow a person to look left and right. The atlanto-axial joints include 3 synovial joints: • Median atlanto-axial joint- The central pivot joint between the dens of the axis and a ring formed 
by the anterior arch and transverse atlantal ligament • Lateral atlanto-axial joints- Plain synovial joints between lateral masses of atlas and upper facets 
of the body of axis Movements at the atlanto-axial joint almost exclusively is rotation around the axis, which help 
side-to-side rotation of the head. The normal range of atlanto-axial rotation is about 40°.

questions.question:
Question 7: An orthopedician performing surgical decompression in a patient with cervical spondylosis 
accidentally damages the transverse atlantal ligament. What is this a component of?
questions.explanation:
The transverse atlantal ligament is a component of the cruciform ligaments at the atlanto-axial 
joints. Cruciform ligaments are shaped like a cross: • The horizontal component of the cross is formed by the transverse atlantal ligament. It is 
attached on each side to the lateral mass of atlas. It retains the dens in position. • The vertical component of the cross is formed by the superior and inferior longitudinal 
ligaments. • Superior longitudinal ligament arises from the upper margin of the transverse atlantal ligament 
and inserts into the basilar part of the occipital bone. • Inferior longitudinal ligament arises from the lower margin of the transverse atlantal ligament 
and inserts to the posterior surface of the axis vertebra. 1136 
Sold by @itachibot Other ligaments at the atlanto-axial joints: • Membrana tectoria- Strong band found inside the vertebral canal, which is the upward 
continuation of the posterior longitudinal ligament • Alar ligaments- Thick cords from the apex of the dens to the medial side of the occipital condyles • Apical ligament of the dens- Connects the apex of dens to the anterior margin of the foramen 
magnum between the alar ligaments

questions.question:
Question 8: A 44-year-old man is brought to the casualty with a suspected whiplash injury following a 
road traffic accident. Which ligament would be injured in this condition? 1128 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a whiplash injury. In this, the anterior longitudinal 
ligament of the spine is damaged. Whiplash is a form of cervical acceleration-deceleration injury. There is hyperextension followed 
by flexion in the recoil. The main pathological features seen in these cases include tear 
(strain) of the anterior longitudinal ligament and the capsular fibers of the facet joints in the 
spine. In some cases, the intervertebral discs may be damaged. Fracture is seen in severe cases 
only. Anterior longitudinal ligament: • It is a strong band that extends along the anterior surface of the vertebral bodies • It extends from the basilar part of the occipital bone to the upper sacrum • It is attached to the anterior tubercle of C1 and the body of C2

questions.question:
Question 9: MRI of a 54-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis showed tectorial membrane 
thickening. This structure is derived from which of the following ligaments?
questions.explanation:
1137 
Sold by @itachibot Membrana tectoria or tectorial membrane is the cranial continuation of the posterior longitudinal 
ligament. The posterior longitudinal ligament is present in the vertebral canal on the posterior surfaces of 
the vertebral bodies. The posterior longitudinal ligaments stretch from the body of the axis (C2) to 
the sacrum. Above the level of axis, the posterior longitudinal ligament continues as membrana tectoria. 
Membrana tectoria extends from the axis to the foramen magnum.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 75-year-old cachexic man presents with nagging back pain in the lumbar region that shoots 
down his right leg. He was diagnosed with prostate cancer 2 months back. Which of the 
following movements is anatomically restricted in the lumbar region?
questions.explanation:
Rotation is anatomically restricted in the lumbar region. The given clinical vignette is suggestive of carcinoma prostate, which has metastasised to the 
lumbar spine. Anatomically, the lumbar region of the vertebral column has a restricted range for 
rotational movements. Movements of the vertebral column: • Flexion of the spine is accompanied by relaxation of the anterior longitudinal ligament and 
compression of the anterior parts of the intervertebral discs. Flexion is effectively absent in the 
thoracic region. Flexion movements are greater than extension or lateral flexion in the lumbar 
region. • Extension is marked in cervical and lumbar regions. It is significantly less at thoracic levels as 
their discs are thinner and because of the ribs and chest musculature. • Lateral flexion is flexion combined with coupled axial rotation. Lateral movements occur in all 
parts of the column but are the greatest in the cervical and lumbar regions. • Axial rotation is the highest in the cervical region, 50% of which occurs at the atlantoaxial joint. 
All the other spine segments below the cervical have only a slight range of rotation, among which 
the thoracolumbar junction has the most. The remainder of the lumbar region has very little 
rotation. 1138 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: An army personnel complains of lower backache following a bullet wound. On examination, 
she has sensory loss on the ipsilateral side below the level of the lesion. What is false about 
the visceral landmarks of the affected structure?

options.a: Heart lies in T5-T8 in recumbent position.
options.b: SVC enters right atrium at T5.
options.c: Azygous vein enters SVC at T5.
options.d: Hemiazygous vein crosses left to right at T5.

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Brown-Sequard syndrome caused due to injury to the 
vertebral column by a bullet wound. The hemiazygous vein crosses from left to right at the level of 
the T8 vertebra (and not T5).

questions.question:
Question 12: The following procedure was planned for a patient with a suspicion of Guillain-Barré 
syndrome. What is not pierced during this procedure?
questions.explanation:
A lumbar puncture is planned for this patient with a suspicion of Guillain-Barré syndrome. The 
posterior longitudinal ligament is not pierced during lumbar puncture. Structures pierced during lumbar puncture (in that order): • Skin • Subcutaneous tissue • Supraspinous ligament • Interspinous ligament • Ligamentum flavum • Epidural space • Dura mater • Arachnoid mater

questions.question:
Question 13: You are asked to auscultate a patient presenting with chronic cough. Which of the following is 
not a boundary of the triangle of auscultation?
questions.explanation:
The serratus anterior is not a boundary of the triangle of auscultation. As there are fewer 
impedances between the examiner's stethoscope and the lungs, this area allows for better 
auscultation of the patient. Boundaries of the triangle of auscultation: • Medially- trapezius muscle’s lateral border • Laterally- scapula’s medial border • Inferiorly- lattssisimus dorsi’s upper border • Floor- 5th and 7th rib, 6th intercostal space, and the rhomboid major The triangle overlies the inferior lobe of both lungs. For exposure of the floor of the triangle, the 
patient needs to fold their arm across their chest to rotate the scapula laterally and bend forward 
resembling somewhat a fetal position. The image given below illustrates the triangle of auscultation. 1139 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
